posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14634037
The Sepent tells the truth, Yahweh is the one lying in the story. Eden never was perfect.

The gods in the story want to keep the Man and the Woman ignorant (specifically on the matter of sexual reproduction). They just want attendants for themselves, if they die they can just create more, but at this phase of things they are able to eat from the tree of life because they're no threat to the gods.
The Serpent, who is one of the elder gods, takes pity on the humans who aren't smart enough to understand how badly they're being fucked over and clues them in that if they eat the fruit from the tree of wisdom then they'll be on par with the gods (able to reproduce).
This is the whole reason the gods need to kick them out of the garden is that if they could reproduce enough to out populate the gods of Yahweh's generation and his sons, then they might be able to kick them out of the garden, which would deprive them of access to the fruit of life.
Which the gods have to continually eat in order to maintain their immortality.
The Serpent for his disloyalty to Yahweh and the younger generation of gods gets his wings clipped and sentenced to slither in the dirt.

Its basically an older and slightly weirder version of the story that was present throughout the region. If you're familiar with the Greek story of Prometheus it should sound pretty familiar.

>How do I learn more about the leviathan?
Leviathan in the story is the embodiment of chaos, the thing 'without form and void'. In the older version of the Genesis account before the scribes who hated fun went in and redacted it out, Yahweh creates the world by killing Leviathan and making the world from its corpse.
Same exact thing Marduk does with Tiamat.

If you've ever been reading your Bible and come across a verse that references Yahweh killing a dragon, and looked for where that happened, it was right at the start, but it got removed.
Of course the Christians remembered this earlier story, and placed it at the end, with Jesus the son of Yahweh (or possibly just Yahweh himself) again slaying Leviathan to re-create the world.

Of course the story itself seems to include the idea of its cyclical nature. So Christians use of it isn't really inappropriate.

>>14636840
Since you have nothing to say, here is a practical demonstration of how hadith work:

>From Ahmad ibn Salih, from Ibn Wahb, from Yunus, from Ibn Shihab, from Sa'id, from Abu Hurairah, from the Prophet
This is a chain of transmission. The job of a hadith scholar(muhaddith) is to look at each person in the chain, inquire about them from other people, ascertain whether each person here is reliable, plausible to have heard the tradition from the person before and whether or not the facts know to them align with the transmission or not.

Al-Bukhari at this time would meet Ahmad ibn Salih personally to inquire about the narration, where he heard it, at what time and whether the narration was verbatim from what Ibn Wahb said. If Ibn Wahb is still alive at that time, he would meet with him, and meet with other people who knew Ibn Wahb to verify that he did indeed say this and that Ahmad ibn Salih narrated it truthfully.

For those not yet alive at that point, he would inquire with people who were still alive, who knew these people, to pore over books of history and inquire on other scholars as to what they know about these people, where they were exactly at the time of narration and validate that nothing was lost after each generation.

Once all these conditions are met and that the narration is attested through other strong chains, then is the hadith accepted as authentically from the prophet or at least from the person who knew the prophet. May people benefit from this knowledge.

>Which ones in particular? I'm personally not the kind to obsess too much over our prehistory, so I won't bite.
I think the conquerors of 896 were pure turks, although they called themselves by some variant of "magyar". all contemporary chronicles call them turks, and I think we should accept this at face value. the ancestor of the language we speak was present in the area before them, at least before 800 judging from the sound values preserved in slavic loanwords (the nasal in galamb, gomba etc.), and it is not at all clear when did it arrive because avars were also turks (iow I do not subscribe to the dual conquest theory). either the avars or even more likely the huns dragged some uralic people with them and left them in place, and aforementioned people went on hunting-fishing-gathering and slowly co-assimilating with the local slavs, giving rise to the hungarian ethnicity but without making history yet (where history means conquest, wars etc.) and therefore invisible to historiography. our earliest traditions as preserved in the chronicles appear to be a mishmash of traditions from the magyar invaders, avars and some reminiscence of having been associated with huns (although everyone and his horse claimed descent from the royal house of the huns, so the hun origin stuff might have been borrowed from either the avars or the magyars).
a scholar named Vékony Gábor appeared to be working towards a different thesis, namely that the entire region between the Danube and the Urals was settled by uralic speakers some time after the IE invasion. his early death at 41 cut this exercise short, and what I saw of it - very little - wasn't too convincing. but it's another theory perhaps worth watching.

Once again, reddit has been proven to be superior to 4chan

I have no comment on why the Chinese seem to prefer to trade with traders rather than go out and explore.

What is known to western history is that China interacted with Northern Australia through trading with the Makassan trepangers commonly associated with Makassar (formerly Ujung Pandang) in southern Sulawesi.

The solid early work on this is due to Campbell Macknight who dated the start of the industry as about 1720, with the earliest recorded trepang voyage made in 1751, before the 1770 voyage of James Cook and the 1788 settlement of Australia.

Sometime after his early work he passed on notes to Regina Ganter of Griffith University regarding the work of a Sulawesi historian that the Top End of Australia had been part of the (Macassan) Kingdom of Gowa since 1640.

The visiting trepanger fleets were actually ethnically diverse, comprising Sama Bajo (sea gypsies), Timorese, Aru Islanders, the captains and crew from Makassar itself, as well as people from other kingdoms in Sulawesi, and even the occasional Chinese trader.

The debate about when contact might have commenced hinges on questions of methodology – to what extent one is prepared to rely on ethnographic, linguistic, and archaeological evidence for events that are outside accepted documented history.

[1] MacKnight,C.C. (1976).The Voyage to Marege': Macassan Trepangers in Northern Australia. Melbourne University

>Russia is thoroughly a middle-income country.
>comparing their quality of life to Italy
So you know, people always talk about Russian oligarchs, a few dozen billionaires who own everything in the country, but ever wondered how the rest of the population fared with the scraps?

Let's take millionaires for example. Now a million bucks sounds like a lot of money to NEETs, but in fact being a millionaire is pretty typical in the West if you're upper-middle class and own a couple of homes, while it's common enough for middle class people to have a quarter million or half a million, mostly invested in their home. It's actually a pretty good metric to check how many people are living comfortably.

So how many millionaires does Russia (pop ~150 million) have? It seems it has 350k or so. Sounds like a lot! But let's see how they compare to other countries.
Well, Denmark (pop 6 million) beats it slightly at 385, Belgium (pop 11 million) has 590k, and Sweden has 610k, meaning it has close to double the amount of millionaires compared to Russia despite having only 10 million people. All of this is thanks to Northern Europe's low GINI coefficient, meaning there's a strong middle and upper-middle class and relative few ultra-rich or ultra-poor people. Just to make sure, we can look at a country with a GINI more comparable to Russia, like Mexico: 320k millionaires among 130 million people, pretty similar to the Russian ratio.
Meanwhile Italy has more than 4 times more millionaires than Russia. That's right, there's close to 1.5 million millionaires in Italy, a country of 65 million people. There's over 2 millions of them in Australia, a country of less than 30 million people. There's some 3.4 million of them in Japan: a country with a bit less pop than Russia has 10x more millionaire. Can you guess how many millionaires the US has? About 25 millions.

tl;dr "middle income" means about as rich as Mexico, you ridiculous vatnik fuck.

>>14632444
There was a plannned operation to invade the USSR with Germany.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantokuen

It was cancelled for multiple reasons:

1. Germany and Japan had no direct communication, in fact their communication after the war broke out was non-existant since the British had severed all axis nations submarine telegraph cables. To coordinate such a incredible operation would have required a lot of communication. Hence why Germany didnt give Japan any notice of their attack on the USSR, and Japan gave Germany no notice on their attack on the US.

2. Japan was extremely reluctant to commit to another land war with no clear strategic objective draining manpower and resources. Siberia had very poor infrastrcture, low urbanisation, and no resources necessary to Japan. Vladivostok would have been the most obvious target, especially since the majority of Lend lease came through there, but other than that the army would be facing the same problems as in China, something it could not afford.

3. Most important reason. USA had put a complete embargo on Japan, most importantly its entire source of oil. This brought the military to a complete standstill, relying solely on its stockpile, and the empire faced economic and social collapse. To begin a new theater of war that would not solve the fundemental critical problem and put a further strain on the military was unacceptable.
Japan had 2 options, end all hostilities and relinquish its territory in China,something that was impossible to fascist ideology, or to capture new sources of raw material.

USA was not the source of these raw materials. That was in British Malaya and Dutch East Indies. Japan attacked USA because USA vowed to declare war on Japan specifically if they attacked these Europeans holdings, the attack on the US was thus in a way "preemptive".

>>14633140
Worth noting that Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's minister of foreign affairs, had also just signed a neutrality pact with the USSR. The fact that he did this shortly after visiting Berlin gave Stalin the assumption it was done with German approval. It was part of why he was so blindsided by Barbarossa in the first place.

But when Matsuoka returned to Japan, one of his biggest priorities wasn't preparing for a two-pronged surprise attack with the Nazis. But reaching a similar diplomatic agreement with the US as he had done with the USSR. It failed because Matsuoka kept trying to placate the military by not ruling out the use of force, alienating the US. While at the same time, Japanese leadership agonized over whether or not America's requested withdrawal from China meant a withdrawal from Manchuria as well (It likely wouldn't have).

there is no empire throughout history that brings as much wonder and curiosity as them, they were essentially snuffed out in their cradle. Pachacuti's empire only lasted a hundred years from his ascension to the Spanish conquest.

He is far more civil engineer than conqueror his government was first and foremost a way to organize labor and resources in order to construct and maintain the many Roads and Andenes throughout the empire, as well as prevent famine and generally improve the living conditions.
This is marked by the fact that the Incas always needed to expand their arable land because each Andean Peasant was ascribed an allotment of land to feed themselves and their village with. in return they would participate in a Corvee for 3 months of the year which they would perform services for the state such as, constructing Andenes, Roads, and participating in the other monumental projects that the empire undertook.
Andenes were raised beds for agriculture built into the sides of mountains and are usually irrigated. they were primarily used to manipulate the soil temperatures to be suitable for three sisters agriculture and plenty of potatoes. these andenes cover about 2.5 million hectares of the former Incan empire but have fallen out of use because you cant use a tractor on them.
The Inca new something many other civilizations have failed to learn. that people can create vast surplus in a inhospitable environment through collective planning and hard work. much akin to the Dutch in the Netherlands but instead of reclaiming land from the sea the Andeans carved it from a dry slab of rock. there are resources about them, they just typically aren't called "Inca" because the Inca had what was essentially institutionalized ethnicities. The Inca themselves referred to the ethnic group from the kingdom of cusco, which ruled over the empire of many other conquered kingdoms and smaller ayllus, which were small clans that belonged to a few villages (which could be spread across vast distances)

so if you want to learn about typical village life in the inca empire, it's going to be different as per the culture - on a universal level, they all were subject to the mit'a and mitma, as well as other forms of taxation, and were offered land and resources like alpacas as well as access to the qapaq nan, and protection. on a more individual level you will have to look at specific cultures - different aymaran cultures, or people like the chancay, chanka, chimor, chachapoyas... there are resources on these peoples but its a bit harder to find.

The Incas basically required that you wear the clothes of your ethnicity and practice your culture - this extended to state systems like the army or corvee labor - you worked with people from your culture

>>14630856
A very recent study on how this appeared in relation to clothing specifically: https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0280511

"Standardization, such as that found in the unku, is likely related to the need of the state to reproduce its symbols of power. Therefore, garments had to adhere as strictly as possible to the standard parameters that gave these pieces an eminently imperial character; however, it has also been pointed out that one of the political strategies of the Inka state was to coordinate the diversity of the peoples, with their different cultures, languages, and traditions, without trying to homogenize them completely. The Inka promoted diversity and allowed local groups to produce material culture and conduct local ritual behavior in ways that represented their ethnic identity [14, 42]. In short, the relationship between the state and local communities was a dialectical process that varied from region to region and village to village, depending on the pressure exerted by the state and the receptivity of local groups [40, 43]. In our opinion, these historical contexts would have generated the conditions for local weavers to introduce morphological, technological, and stylistic features with low visibility, attributes which did not radically transform the imperial character of these iconic objects that represented the state."

there's still a level of assimilation involved - the state did have a lot of control over its subjects, especially compared to another empire like the aztecs for example. but they certainly organized the imperial structure around ethnicity. Entire cultures were treated depending on how loyal they were as subjects, or in the short term if they fought against conquest or simply accepted it. loyal ayllus were sent to the frontiers of the empire to develop it while the less loyal were brought close to cuzco to be more easily controlled

>>14630549
Compared to a utopia without violence, violence does not make things better and violence is never justified. However this is a useless conclusion. This is not a utopia. Violence is an inherent part of this world. Violence by individuals, violence by gangs, violence by the masses, violence by authoritarian states. Violence is inevitable. Even with the liberal/libertarian/anarchist mindset, it is a reality one must accept. The real question is how one should react to violence.

In a democracy the masses will inevitably use violence against property owners, they are clothed in overwhelming force and can seize property in a heartbeat. Therefore there is a constant battle against the mob. Thankfully market forces are on the side of liberty, as we can see in places like Venezuela, attempts to seize property have catastrophic effects.

1: it causes economic collapse, most businesses run on the assumption their investments will pay off after a long period, usually 10 to 20 years in competitive capital markets, if there is no guarantee of this they simply won't bother doing business
2: little seized property is ever redistributed to the masses, rather the corrupt party elite hold onto it for themselves, their socialist or communist ideology is no guarantee they will act benevolently
3: the new regime fails to develop surrogates for a free market, a black market thrives while government services end up inept and inefficient, either due to corruption or due to the "top heavy" nature of a planned economy and administrative inefficiency

The raison d'être of a business therefore is that it provides a service more efficiently than the government could. If it cannot then the state will take over. Additionally those who value liberty must organize to place every obstacle, legal or otherwise, in the way of those who seek to undermine the market, generally making it as expensive as possible for the state to take even 1 step in that direction.

If you read General Norman Schwarzkopf's memoirs and books, you kind of get the picture that he is a man of quiet humility. He didn't boast much. I think the main reason Gulf War 1 doesn't get much fanfare is because it was quick short and efficient with only one moment of overwhelming glory at 73 Eastings which overshadowed the Battle at Medina Ridge and the Battle of Norfolk. The main takeaways that were gained from Gulf War in general was:

-Maneuver Warfare is highly effective
-GPS tech provided an extremely effective battlefield enhancement
-Low Command (Lt - Captains) initiative can monumentally be valuable
-A volunteer army is a highly professional force and conscription is not as necessary as it was presumed
-Logistics continues to be a key lynch pin to any operation

posts.sub: Why is the American eastcoast so devoid of ancient ruins???
posts.com:
This seems like an unexplored mystery to me. It doesn't make any sense, let's address possible explanations.

>The climate is not preservative

While true, there are ruins in literal jungles in Central America and asia.

>The people's were too primitive to make stone structure.

Native Americans were allegedly asiatic and asiatic ppls from all over the globe created complex societies that left stone ruins. I guess one could make the argument that they inherited semi-nomadic traits from thier Siberian ancestors, however Siberians not only domesticated horses, but built thier nomadic lifestyles around horsemanship, while native Americans wiped out north American horses.

>The population density never reached the critical level necessary for complex societies.

This is a very real possibility due to the fact that it has so much habitable land, even then, populations would have likely coalesced around rivers for fresh water, but not too far from the ocean for easy access to salt, essentially the regions that hold the majority of the modern eastern seaboard population.

Those are the obvious go to explanations for the mysterious lack of ancient ruins, but imo, none are really sound so I present the following possibility:

>They were destroyed by religiously zealous Christian settlers in an act of historically hidden iconoclastic destruction.

It's not unusual for ancient works to be destroyed by religious fundamentalists viewing them as heathenistic idolatry, it even happens to this very day, see ISIL. Thus I believe the true explanation to the mystery could lie in religious fundamentalism of the early European settlers. Monoliths, temples and religious sites could have likely been destroyed without a trace then modern American cities built overtop of where they once stood.

posts.sub: The problem of evil is still unresolved
posts.com:
>If God is all good all loving all knowing and all powerful why does he allow so much pointless suffering to happen? Like rape, torture, genocide, birth defects, children with cancer, etc
The most common answer is “free will” but there are 3 huge problems with that

1. Omniscience Paradox
Strict Determinist: If God is all knowing we don’t have free will because he knows everything that we will do in the future, which means the future is predetermined. He already knows who will or will not die a sinner the moment they are born. If God is omniscient he already knows what he will do in the future too, which means he also lacks free will. If you follow the Bible literally that means God deliberately set mankind up to fail
Compatibilist: God can create a world where we theoretically could sin, but no one would actually want to do it so it never happens. However he hasn’t done that

2. Heaven and free will
If Heaven has free will then God is capable of creating a world of eternal bliss with no suffering, that also has free will, yet doesn’t do that

If Heaven lacks free will then free will isn’t particularly valuable. We will spend eternity with no free will anyways, our short lives with free will is working towards this as a goal. Religion portrays Heaven as a reward, something desirable, so it is admitting that an eternity of bliss with no free will is preferable over a short life filled with suffering with free will.

3. Degree of evil
God can create an exact replica of our current world, but make one heinous evil impossible to commit, like rape. We would still have free will and live in an objectively better world

If you object and say that isn’t free will, the rebuttal is God decides what is or isn’t possible. I can’t phase through walls or stop time in this world, does that mean I lack free will? Why can’t God just make rape impossible then?

>>14634035
All Sura 65:4 tells us is that it is permissible in Islam to marry women (and the word used in the Arabic is specifically women not children or girls) who haven't had their periods yet. We have sources from 19th century England that put the typical age of menarche there at 14-17 years old - this is higher than for young women today because of changes in diet and nutrition. Indeed, amenorrhea is common amongst malnourished women (it's most prevalent amongst women with eating disorders in the modern era) and it's not difficult to imagine young women living in a literal desert backwater town having the kind of diet that would lead to late menarche.

Given how unreliable and politically motivated the sources in the Aisha-was-a-child-bride hadith are, I wouldn't take that as justification for child marriage either. If I were a Hanafi Imam or Qadi, I would consider it mandatory for the bride to consent to the marriage contract by signing it herself (this is the established position within that school). She would obviously be in no position to consent to such a contract as a child nor would she be in a position to consummate her marriage at that point either (an important element within any marriage contract). As a consequence, I wouldn't consider any marriage contract to be valid until the bride is an adult. It's difficult to set a specific age for that. Marriageable age laws and age of consent laws in Europe tend to put that threshold between 14 and 18 - that's the range I'd be looking at myself. The notion that anyone could officiate the marriage of anyone younger than that seems absurd to me.

>>14634582
Kind of like >>14634594 said, the Argument from Motion could at best be an argument for Deism. God had one line in history's script, that was "let there be light" and then he got the fuck out of the way. Might even be true for all I know, we don't have any better ideas so far for why matter and consciousness exist.

But I don't want to give Aquinas that much credit. That whole argument is based on a really common fallacy--where you build up a useful and descriptive metaphor or lens for describing real-world events, and then try to treat that metaphor as a solid fact on which you can prove a point.

Communists do the same thing all the time. There's nothing wrong with describing a society in terms of the "means of production", "mode of production" "bourgeoisie", "proletariat", etc. You can look at any society and identify those things, and sometimes that's actually a useful way to analyze them. But once you've accepted that "means of production" and the "proletariat" are a thing, communists will assert that it is absolute proof that the right or correct future for society is that the proletariat seize the means of production, and they seem to have an airtight rationale for doing so.

But that argument is all based on nothing more than a useful metaphor. "Means of production" aren't a real or universal or true thing. They're an artificial category we slap over things to help make sense of them in a certain light. Useful as far as it goes, but no basis for proving any kind of supposed universal or objective truth.

"potentials" and "actuals" are no more valid of a basis for proving anything than "means of production" or the "proletariat".

You're missing my point. I'm challenging the assertion that "potentials" and "actuals" and "motion" are a valid way of describing how the world works at all, and worthy of using as a basis to make such claims as that there is a God who created the universe. It sounds really deep and wise and philosophical at first blush, but there is no substance to it.

Aquinas is sneaking in an assertion as he frames his question, and it's that assertion that needs to be challenged:

>Aquinas is not arguing for a beginning to the universe, but rather for a causal power that is operating right now.

That's assuming you already agree with half his premise--that there is a difference between the chain of cause and effect through time since the beginning of the universe (if it even had a beginning--I also dispute the assertion that it might not be infinite through time as well as space), and the chain of cause and effect that causes things to be "actualized" within any given moment.

That whole assertion is made up and I'm not sure what his basis is for it. The causes for what things are and where they are, how they behave and how they move, in any given moment, are in the previous moment. The chain of cause and effect is entirely material, and it is absolute. If you could hypothetically know about the nature of, and forces acting upon, every single particle of matter following the Big Bang, you'd have a perfect and complete roadmap of the way the universe would progress in the future, down to what you ate for breakfast this morning. "motion" is real, sure, but things will only move in one way. Unless the multiversefags are right, things have only happened one way, and only will happen one way, regarding every single thing in the universe, from stars and supernovas to ants and dust mites.

>inb4 yeah but what's before the Big Bang
Don't know. But even though it sounds counterintuitive--there's no reason this chain of material causality could not be infinite.

According to Stephanie Mawson in her M.Phil thesis entitled Between Loyalty and Disobedience: The Limits of Spanish Domination in the Seventeenth Century Pacific, in the 1600s there were thousands of Latin American settlers sent to the Philippines by the Spaniards per year and around that time frame the Spaniards had cumulatively sent 15,600 settlers from Peru and Mexico[4] while there were only 600 Spaniards from Spain,[5] that supplemented a Philippine population of only 667,612 people.[6] Due to the initial low population count, people of Latin American and Hispanic descent quickly spread across the territory.[7] The book, "Intercolonial Intimacies Relinking Latin/o America to the Philippines, 1898–1964 By Paula C. Park" citing "Forzados y reclutas: los criollos novohispanos en Asia (1756-1808)" gave a higher number of later Mexican soldier-immigrants to the Philippines, pegging the number at 35,000 immigrants in the 1700s,[8] in a Philippine population which was only around 1.5 Million, thus forming 2.33% of the population.[9] As a result, German ethnographer Fedor Jagor, using Spanish censuses, estimated that one-third of the island of Luzon, which holds half of the Philippine population, had varying degrees of Spanish and Latin American ancestry.[10] Corroborating these Spanish era estimates, an anthropological study published in the Journal of Human Biology and researched by Matthew Go, using physical anthropology, concluded that 12.7% of Filipinos can be classified as Hispanic (Latin American mestizos or Malay-Spanish mestizos), 7.3% as Indigenous American, African at 4.5% and European at 2.7%. Pennsylvania was solidly Democrat from the 1800 election until the Civil War, with Philly being a Federalist/Whig stronghold and part of Andrew Jackson's campaign against the BOTUS was due to it being headquartered there and keeping the city a nagging center of Federalist influence in the state. It was one of a few states Hoover carried in 1932 as Philadelphia mayor Harry Mackey got out just enough votes in the city to tip the state Republican.

PA was generally a swing state from the 1930s to 80s until it became Democrat-dominated in the 90s-2000s but is returning to a swing state since Trump.

In the 18th century the Indians were considered barbarians because they weren't Christian, but in the 19th century the way Europeans thought about the world had become a lot more scientific and there was a lot more focus on biology and race. By the 1850s there was a growing sense of racial (rather than just religious or cultural) superiority, which discouraged inter-racial couples.

Yes. That was the set up the BEIC came up with as - again - they weren't all that concerned with Imperial Prestige, or even tax collection but with keeping their costs down and revenue up. Keeping 'The Princely States' as the nominal rulers (as long as the Prince understands that his 'adviser' is actually calling the shots, and that breaking his treaties with the Britishers will result in thousands of riflemen and artillery showing up in his front garden) limited problems and kept costs down nicely. By the time the rule of British India was passed on to the state it was just more hassle than it was worth to try to change that set up significantly. There are several stories of British diplomats and administrators trying support claimants to various princely states who would play ball with them - but it's hard to pin down exactly how much that happened or how much of a big deal it was, as every historian who deals with the issue will have an impact on whether he's trying to downplay or exaggerate the claims and evidence.

Socrates, Jesus, and Joan of Arc were all individuals who challenged the dominant beliefs and authorities of their time.

Socrates was a philosopher in ancient Greece who questioned the conventional wisdom of his day and encouraged his followers to do the same. He was eventually put on trial and sentenced to death for his ideas.

Jesus was a religious leader in Judea who challenged the religious and political authorities of his time, advocating for a radical interpretation of Judaism and promoting compassion, forgiveness, and equality. He was eventually executed by the Roman authorities.

Joan of Arc was a young woman from France who claimed to have received divine messages urging her to lead the French army against the English during the Hundred Years' War. She dressed as a man and fought in battles, inspiring her countrymen with her bravery and piety. She was eventually captured by the English, tried for heresy, and burned at the stake.

All three of these individuals challenged the status quo and were persecuted for their beliefs, but their legacies have endured and continue to inspire people to this day.

>The Romans, Greeks and medieval Europeans had positional notation
Lol do you even know what positional notation is? It means using a zero to create a counting system which cycles the same digits over into new columns, periodically. It's way easier to calculate with, but you can't do that without a consistent zero, and romans didn't use zero.

>source?

FD's autobiography, the Narrative, and his complexion. Perhaps also his intelligence? His probable father, Aaron Anthony, was the lead overseer/accountant at the wealthy Lloyd plantation on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Seeing young Freddy's intelligence, Anthony's daughter, Lucretia, arranged for him to be removed from the plantation and sent to Hugh Auld to be a house slave in Baltimore - a significant step up from plantation life. (Hugh was the brother of Thomas Auld, who married Anthony's daughter, Lucretia.)

The landscape of Douglass' life changed from a countryside to a city, and it is a change that he credits as a major influence on his life. Mrs. Auld took a liking to the young Douglass, and began to teach him to read, however, once Mr. Auld discovered the lessons, he ordered a halt to it at once. The short exposure to reading and writing sparked Douglass’ interest and he wanted to know more.

Douglass would eventually quench his thirst for learning in his seven years of service under the Aulds. It should be noted that by being in a city like Baltimore, Douglass was granted a number of liberties that helped in his pursuit that would not have been afforded to him at his old home on the Eastern Shore. Though his master Hugh forbid him to read, Douglass used Baltimore’s streets as his classroom. In his Narrative, he says that he learned from the white boys he met on the street, bargaining treats for a lesson in ABC’s. He would also go to the ship yard and observe the writings on cargo to learn how to form letters.

When Lucretia died, Thomas Auld reclaimed Frederick. This began three years of toil in plantation fields, both Auld's and others. After trying to escape from the farm of Mr. Freeland, who rented him from Auld, Douglass was sent to the slave-breaker Covey.

The battle between these two makes for a fascinating part of his biography, recounted initially in his shortest and arguably best book, the Narrative. Well worth reading.

>I lived with Mr. Covey one year. During the first six months scarce a week passed without his whipping me. I was seldom free from a sore back. We were often in the field from the first approach of day till its last lingering ray had left us; midnight often caught us in the field binding blades.

>Mr. Covey was one of the few slaveholders who could and did work with his hands. He was a hard-working man. He knew by himself just what a man or a boy could do. There was no deceiving him. His work went on in his absence almost as well as in his presence; and he had the faculty of making us feel that he was ever present with us. This he did by surprising us. He seldom approached the spot where we were at work openly, if he could do it secretly. He always aimed at taking us by surprise. Such was his cunning, that we used to call him, among ourselves, "the snake." When we were at work in the cornfield, he would sometimes crawl on his hands and knees to avoid detection, and all at once he would rise nearly in our midst, and scream out, "Ha, ha! Come, come!" His comings were like a thief in the night. He appeared to us as being ever at hand. He was under every tree, behind every stump, in every bush, and at every window. He would sometimes mount his horse, as if bound to St. Michael's, a distance of seven miles, and in half an hour afterwards you would see him coiled up in the corner of the wood-fence, watching every motion of the slaves. Again, he would sometimes walk up to us, and give us orders as though he was upon the point of starting on a long journey, turn his back upon us, and make as though he was going to the house to get ready; and, before he would get half way thither, he would turn short and crawl into a fence-corner, or behind some tree, and there watch us till the going down of the sun.

>We were worked in all weathers. It was never too hot or too cold; it could never rain, blow, hail, or snow, too hard for us to work in the field. Work, work, work, was scarcely more the order of the day than of the night. The longest days were too short for him, and the shortest nights too long for him.

>I was somewhat unmanageable when I first went there, but a few months of this discipline tamed me. Mr. Covey succeeded in breaking me. I was broken in body, soul, and spirit. My natural elasticity was crushed, my intellect languished, the disposition to read departed, the cheerful spark that lingered about my eye died; the dark night of slavery closed in upon me; and behold a man transformed into a brute!

>Sunday was my only leisure time. I spent this in a sort of beast-like stupor, between sleep and wake, under some large tree. At times I would rise up, a flash of energetic freedom would dart through my soul, accompanied with a faint beam of hope, that flickered for a moment, and then vanished. I sank down again, mourning over my wretched condition. I was sometimes prompted to take my life, and that of Covey, but was prevented by a combination of hope and fear. My sufferings on this plantation seem now like a dream rather than a stern reality.

>Our house stood within a few rods of the Chesapeake Bay, whose broad bosom was ever white with sails from every quarter of the habitable globe.

>Those beautiful vessels, robed in purest white, so delightful to the eye of freemen, were to me so many shrouded ghosts, to terrify and torment me with thoughts of my wretched condition. I have often, in the deep stillness of a summer's Sabbath, stood all alone upon the banks and traced, with saddened heart and tearful eye, the countless number of sails moving off to the mighty ocean. The sight of these always affected me powerfully. My thoughts would compel utterance; and there, with no audience but the Almighty, I would pour out my soul's complaint.

>You are loosed from your moorings, and are free; I am fast in my chains, and am a slave! You move merrily before the gentle gale, and I sadly before the bloody whip! You are freedom's swift-winged angels, that fly round the world; I am confined in bands of iron! O that I were free! O, that I were on one of your gallant decks, and under your protecting wing! Alas! betwixt me and you, the turbid waters roll. Go on, go on. O that I could also go! Could I but swim! If I could fly!

>O, why was I born a man, of whom to make a brute. The glad ship is gone; she hides in the dim distance. I am left in the hottest hell of unending slavery. O God, save me! God, deliver me! Let me be free! Is there any God? Why am I a slave? I will run away. I will not stand it. Get caught, or get clear, I'll try it. I had as well die with ague as the fever. I have only one life to lose. I had as well be killed running as die standing. Only think of it; one hundred miles straight north, and I am free! Try it? Yes! God helping me, I will. It cannot be that I shall live and die a slave.

>Meanwhile, I will try to bear up under the yoke. I am not the only slave in the world. Why should I fret? I can bear as much as any of them. There is a better day coming.

>Thus I used to think, and thus I used to speak to myself; goaded almost to madness at one moment, and at the next reconciling myself to my wretched lot.

>You have seen how a man was made a slave; you shall see how aslave was made a man.

>On one of the hottest days of the month of August, 1833, Bill Smith, William Hughes, a slave named Eli, and myself, were engaged in fanning wheat. Hughes was clearing the fanned wheat from before the fan, Eli was turning, Smith was feeding, and I was carrying wheat to the fan. The work was simple, requiring strength rather than intellect; yet, to one entirely unused to such work, it came very hard. About three o'clock of that day, I broke down; my strength failed me; I was seized with a violent aching of the head, attended with extreme dizziness. When I could stand no longer, I fell, and felt as held down by an immense weight.

>Mr. Covey was at the house, about one hundred yards from the treading-yard. On hearing the fan stop, he left immediately and came to the spot where we were.

>I had by this time crawled away under the side of the rail-fence, hoping to find relief by getting out of the sun. He came to the spot, and, after looking at me awhile, asked me what was the matter. I told him as well as I could, for I scarce had strength to speak. He then gave me a savage kick in the side, and told me to get up. I tried to do so, but fell back in the attempt. He gave me another kick, and again told me to rise. I again tried, staggered and fell. Mr. Covey took up the hickory slat and gave me a heavy blow upon the head, making a large wound, and the blood ran freely; and with this again told me to get up. I made no effort to comply, having now made up my mind to let him do his worst. In a short time after receiving this blow, my head grew better. Mr. Covey had now left me to my fate. At this moment I resolved, for the first time, to go to my master, enter a complaint, and ask his protection. In order to this, I must that afternoon walk seven miles. I watched my chance, and while Covey was looking in an opposite direction, started for St. Michael's.
